raw_text:
Stock market eyes Japan recovery
 
 Japanese shares have ended the year at their highest level since 13 July amidst hopes of an economic recovery during 2005.
 
 The Nikkei index of leading shares gained 7.6% during the year to close at 11,488.76 points. In 2005 it "will rise toward 13,000", predicted Morgan Stanley equity strategist Naoki Kamiyama. The optimism in the financial markets contrast sharply with pessimism in the Japanese business community. Earlier this month, the quarterly Tankan survey of Japanese manufacturers found that business confidence had weakened for the first time since March 2003.
 
 Slower economic growth, rising oil prices, a stronger yen and weaker exports were blamed for the fall in confidence. Despite this, traders expect strength in the global economy to benefit Japan, which has been close to sliding into recession in recent months. Structural reform within Japan and an anticipated end to the banking sector's bad debt problems should also help, they say.
llama3.2:1b: Japanese shares ended the year at their highest level since July 2005, with the Nikkei index rising 7.6% to close at 11,488.76 points.
Despite recent weakness in business confidence, optimistic forecasts from equity strategist Naoki Kamiyama predicted a rise in the market to around 13,000 by 2005.
llama3.2:3b: Japanese shares ended the year at their highest level since July 2005, with a 7.6% gain, amid hopes of an economic recovery.
The optimism contrasts with pessimism in the Japanese business community, which cited slower growth, rising oil prices, and weaker exports as factors.
Despite this, traders expect the global economy's strength to benefit Japan, driven by structural reform and an anticipated end to bad debt problems.
gemma2:2b: Japanese stock market rose significantly year-end.
The Nikkei index gained 7.6% and is predicted to reach 13,000 in 2005.

Despite a decline in business confidence for the first time since March 2003 due to slower economic growth, rising oil prices, a stronger yen, and weaker exports, traders anticipate global economic strength will benefit Japan.
Structural reform and an expected end of banking sector bad debt problems are expected to further help.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Japanese stock markets have recorded their highest point since July 13.
In 2005, it was expected that the Nikkei index would reach 13,000 points.
However, this was not realized due to economic growth放缓、油价攀升、日本企业信心减弱以及出口商品价格上升等不利因素。
qwen2.5:1.5b: Japanese shares hit record highs as market optimism persists despite economic challenges.
Expectations for continued growth point towards a recovery that could reach 13,000 points by year-end.
Despite concerns over slower growth, rising oil prices, and the yen's strength, traders expect global economy benefits to bolster Japan.
Structural reforms within Japan and an anticipated end to banking bad debt issues are also seen as positive factors.
qwen2.5:3b: Japanese shares ended the year at their highest level since July, up 7.6% to 11,488.76 points.
The Nikkei index is expected to reach 13,000 in 2005 according to Naoki Kamiyama of Morgan Stanley.
However, optimism contrasts with pessimism among the Japanese business community.
A recent Tankan survey showed a decline in business confidence for the first time since March 2003, attributed to slower economic growth, rising oil prices, a stronger yen, and weaker exports.
Despite these issues, traders expect global strength to benefit Japan, which has avoided recession recently.
Structural reform within Japan and an end to banking sector bad debt problems are also seen as positive factors.
opencoder:1.5b:
The summary of the provided text is as follows:

Japan’s stock market recovery, followed by a sharp rise in the Nikkei index of leading shares during 2005, predicted by Naoki Kamiyama's Morgan Stanley, has reshaped the financial landscape.
The anticipation and expectation of growth indicate stronger confidence in the global economy, which is poised to slow down.
Business confidence has dropped markedly, with slower economic growth due to rising oil prices and a weaker export situation.

However, traders anticipate strength in the global economy to benefit Japan, as it has been moving sluggishly since March 2003, during which time Japanese businesses struggled with their bad debt problems.
smollm:1.7b: The Japanese stock market recovered from a low point in 2005, driven by strong corporate earnings growth and a rebound in consumer spending.
The Nikkei index of leading shares gained 7.6% during the year to close at 11,488.
In 2005 it "will rise toward 13,000", predicted Morgan Stanley equity strategist Naoki Kamiyama.
The optimism in the financial markets contrasts sharply with pessimism in the Japanese business community.
Later this month, the quarterly Tankan survey of Japanese manufacturers found that business confidence had weakened for the first time since March 2003.
Despite this, traders expect strength in the global economy to benefit Japan, which has been close to sliding into recession in recent months.
Structural reform within Japan and an anticipated end to the banking sector's bad debt problems should also help, they say.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Japanese shares ended the year at their highest level since July 2005 with hopes of recovery during 2005.
The Nikkei index of leading shares gained 7.6% during the year, closing at 11,488.76 points.
Morgan Stanley's equity strategist predicted the Nikkei would rise towards 13,000 in 2005 but also mentioned that business optimism is counterbalanced by pessimism in Japan.
In April, a Tankan survey found business confidence weakened since March 2003 for the first time due to slower growth, rising oil prices, stronger yen, and weaker exports.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Japanese stock market has experienced a significant recovery during 2005, reaching its highest level since July 13 with a rise of 7.6% compared to the previous year.
The optimism in the financial markets contrasts sharply with the pessimism within the Japanese business community.

A quarterly survey of Japanese manufacturers found a weakening of business confidence for the first time in nearly two years, but economists predict that a boost to global economic growth and potential for stronger exports could benefit Japan.
Despite these factors, trade professionals forecast further strength in the global economy as well as a recovery from recent recessionary trends in Japan.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The summary statement is: "Stock market eyes Japan recovery - Japanese shares ended the year at their highest level since 13th July amidst optimism of economic recovery."
The main ideas conveyed are that Japanese shares had reached a new high during this year, while the expectations for an economic recovery in 2005 are increasing.
The reasons behind these positive sentiments are mainly attributed to optimism about business confidence and other key factors impacting the global economy.
phi:2.7b: Japanese shares ended the year at their highest level since July 13, 2005, with the Nikkei index of leading shares gaining 7.6% during the year to close at 11,488.76 points.

Despite concerns over slower economic growth, rising oil prices, a stronger yen, and weaker exports, traders expect strength in the global economy to benefit Japan, which has been close to recession in recent months.
Structural reform within Japan and an anticipated end to the banking sector' bad debt problems should also help boost the stock market.
orca-mini:3b: The stock market is optimistic about Japan's economic recovery in 2005 due to rising oil prices, a stronger yen, weaker exports, and stronger global economy.
However, traders still expect strength in the global economy to benefit Japan, which has been close to sliding into recession in recent months.
Structural reform within Japan and an anticipated end to bad debt problems in the banking sector are also expected to help.
hermes3:3b: Japanese shares reach highest level, expecting 13000 by 2005 due to economic recovery hopes.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Japanese shares closed at their highest level since 13 July, with the Nikkei index gaining 7.6% in 2004, predicting a rise toward 13,000 in 2005.

Despite financial markets optimism and contrasting pessimism within the Japanese business community due to slower economic growth, rising oil prices, a stronger yen, and weaker exports, traders still expect strength in the global economy to benefit Japan.
Structural reform within the country and an end to banking sector bad debt problems are also seen as potential helpers.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Japanese shares ended the year at their highest level since July, driven by hopes of economic recovery in 2005.
The Nikkei index rose 7.6% to 11,488.76 points, with predictions it could reach 13,000.
However, business confidence has weakened due to slower growth, rising oil prices, a stronger yen, and weaker exports.
Despite this, traders expect global economic strength, structural reforms, and resolution of banking sector debt issues to support Japan’s recovery.
stablelm2:1.6b: Japanese shares reached their highest point since July due to economic recovery hopes.
The Nikkei index increased 7.6% for the year ending at 2013's closing price, projected to rise further in 2015.

However, Japanese business confidence has weakened amid slower growth, rising oil prices, a stronger yen, and weaker exports; despite this, traders expect global economic strength and structural reform within Japan and banking sector issues resolving will help boost Japan's economy.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Japanese shares concluded 2004 at their highest point since July 13, rising 7.6% to 11,488.76 points on the Nikkei index.
Morgan Stanley's Naoki Kamiyama predicts a further rise towards 13,000 in 2005.

This optimism contrasts with faltering business confidence among Japanese manufacturers, as indicated by the quarterly Tankan survey, due to factors like slower economic growth, escalating oil prices, a stronger yen, and weaker exports.

Despite these challenges, traders anticipate global economic strength will propel Japan out of potential recession, while structural reforms and resolution of the banking sector's bad debt issues are also expected to contribute positively.
